question: When considering an Application for Listing, what actions may the Regulator take regarding admission of Securities to the Official List, and how does the authority under section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR relate to the circumstance-based power described in subsection (2)?
source_text: Under section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR, the Regulator may impose conditions or restrictions in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List, or vary or withdraw such conditions or restrictions.
target_text:
The Regulator may—
(a)	refuse an Application for Listing; or
(b)	impose conditions or restrictions, in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List, or vary or withdraw such conditions or restrictions;
in the circumstances specified in subsection ‎(2).

question: Where an Applicant/Authorised Person seeks FSRA approval for its FSP to cover a Regulated Activity in relation to both conventional assets (e.g., Securities or Derivatives) and Spot Commodities, how should the fee outcome be determined if the Regulator considers it fair and reasonable to reduce, waive or refund fees in that particular case?
source_text:
FEES
Cumulative application of Fees
Noting the above paragraph, if an Applicant/Authorised Person will be undertaking a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets (e.g., Securities or Derivatives) in addition to Spot Commodities, it will need to seek approval from the FSRA for its FSP to permit it to carry out its Regulated Activity in relation to both asset types (conventional and Spot Commodities).  The fees attributable to that Authorised Person for its Regulated Activities, conventional and Spot Commodity-related, may not be cumulative should the FSRA apply its discretion to reduce or waive a fee, under FEES 1.2.8 (considering the high fees already imposed on Applicants/Authorised Persons conducting Regulated Activities using Spot Commodities.

Relief from Payment

question: Where an Issuer makes an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and has published a Prospectus, what must the Issuer (or the person responsible for the issue of the Prospectus) do if, after the Prospectus is issued, a significant change occurs or a material mistake/inaccuracy or significant new matter arises, and what baseline prospectus requirement anchors this obligation?
source_text: Regulatory treatment of tokens deemed to be Securities. The requirements for Offers of Securities fall under Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules (“MKT”). When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, these requirements include, for example, the obligation to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR.
target_text:
Prospectus requirement. Obligation to issue a supplementary prospectus
If at any time after the issue of a Prospectus there is a significant change in, or a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting any matter contained in the Prospectus or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer or the person responsible for the issue of the Prospectus shall issue a supplementary prospectus which—
(a)	provides details of the change, mistake, inaccuracy or new matter; and
(b)	complies with the requirements in section ‎62‎(1).

question: Where the Regulator considers a name issue under Section 117 of FSMR, how does the Regulator’s power to make a direction apply across (i) a Fund, (ii) a Sub-Fund, and (iii) a class of Units in a Fund, and what specific action may the Regulator require and from whom when the name is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with another name?
source_text: Pursuant to Section 117 of FSMR, the Regulator has the power to make a direction if a name of a Fund, Sub-Fund or class of Units in a Fund is undesirable, misleading or conflicts with a name used by another Fund, Sub-Fund or class of Units of a Fund.
target_text:
Power to make a Direction
If, in the opinion of the Regulator, the name of a Fund or of a Sub Fund conflicts with the name of another Fund or Sub-Fund or is undesirable or misleading, it may direct the Fund Manager to change the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that does not follow a non-mandatory requirement in a Mining Reporting Standard (for example, a non-mandatory item in Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code), what must the Mining Reporting Entity include in the disclosure, and how does this relate to the Regulator’s expectation of compliance under Rule 11.2.1(1) and the explanation approach referenced in Rule 11.2.2?
source_text: Rule 11.2.1(1) requires a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all binding requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard. The Regulator also expects a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all non-mandatory requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard, including, for example, Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code, or explain its non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2.
target_text: Requirements for all disclosures. Where a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in a Mining Reporting Standard, the Mining Reporting Entity must provide in its disclosure a statement as to how and why its disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard.

The Regulator also expects a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all non-mandatory requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard, including, for example, Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code, or explain its non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2.

question: If a Listed Entity hasn’t fully followed APP 4, what does it need to say in its annual financial report, and what extra disclosure does the Regulator expect in the Prospectus and later under Rule 9.2.10—and what happens if the statements are inaccurate or false?
source_text: Generally, if a Reporting Entity does not adopt the best practice standards set out in APP 4, or adopts them only partially, the Regulator would expect the reasons for doing so and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the outcomes intended by the Corporate Governance Principles to be disclosed in the Prospectus and thereafter pursuant to the Disclosure required under Rule 9.2.10. Any inaccurate or false representations would lead to the imposition of civil liability in accordance with section 70 of the FSMR.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: When an Authorised Person is establishing and maintaining systems and controls to deter/prevent and report suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes, how should it reflect best practices given the evolving nature of Financial Crime, and what concrete measures are indicated as examples for those systems and controls?

Such practices may include, but are not limited to, incorporating secure authentication, biometrics and the monitoring of customer behaviour metrics into anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems and controls.

question: If an ADGM Green Portfolio has (1) assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy under Rule 3.8.4(a) and (2) assets that track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark under Rule 3.8.4(b), which part needs the third-party attestation and how often must it be done?
source_text: Under Rule 3.8.6, the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets which are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark in accordance with Rule ‎3.8.4(b).

This requirement only applies to that portion of the Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy in accordance with Rule ‎3.8.4(a). This requirement is referred to as the “Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement”.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity says its economic assumptions are “commercially sensitive” in a Rule 11.9.1 forecast disclosure, what must it still explain, and when might it be hard to justify calling those assumptions sensitive? Also, what must it disclose about the Production Target used for the forecast?
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text: ORE RESERVES . Mining Reporting Entities need to be careful not to claim that information is commercially sensitive when this is not the case.  If a Mining Reporting Entity, for example, has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin its commodity price, capital expenditure or operational expenditure assumptions, it would be difficult to form a view that information about those assumptions would be commercially sensitive.

question: How would the Regulator assess whether a trader’s conduct in a crude oil contract—rapidly accumulating more than 90% of the physical inventory, not offering to lend it back at a reasonable commercial rate, and then unwinding in the final settlement window at rapidly increasing prices—amounts to Behaviour that secures an abnormal or artificial price level, given the requirement that the transactions or orders be otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices?
source_text:
Abusive squeezes. The following are specific examples of an abusive squeeze that, in the Regulator's view, may contravene section 92 (4)(b):
(a)	during the course of a trading day on a Commodity Derivative Exchange, a trader rapidly builds up a position of more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract.  The trader fails to Offer to lend the crude oil back to other market participants at a reasonable commercial rate.  The trader then unwinds his position in the Exchange's final settlement window  at rapidly increasing prices, thereby cornering/squeezing the crude oil market.  His conduct causes an abnormal movement in the price of crude oil contracts for forward month delivery; and
(b)	a trader with a long position in bond futures, buys or borrows a large amount of the bonds and either refuses to re-lend these bonds or will only lend them to parties he believes will not re-lend to the market.  His purpose is to position the price at which persons with short positions have to deliver to satisfy their obligations at a materially higher level, making him a profit on his position.
target_text:
The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which—
(a)	give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or
(b)	secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, how should eligible financial Collateral be determined when the proposed Collateral is an instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5 but is a T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by an entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person and held as Collateral by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities?
source_text: For the purposes of Rule 4.13.5 and 4.13.6, eligible financial Collateral excludes any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person, which is held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral.
target_text:
For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises:
(a)	any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5;
(b)	any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and
(c)	any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where:
(i)	a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and
(ii)	at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: If the Regulator gets the Rule 3.2.2 notice and normally would tell the Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days about using the passporting procedures, when is it not allowed to send the notice under Rule 3.2.4(a), and what does that mean for publishing the Passported Fund details and telling the Fund Manager registration is complete?
source_text:
The Regulator shall not transmit a notice under Rule 3.2.4‎(a):
(a)	if it considers that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund does not comply with, or it has reasonable grounds for determining that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund may in the future not comply with, applicable legislation, including these Rules; or
(b)	if it considers that it is necessary and appropriate to refrain from doing so in order to meet its objectives.
target_text:
The Regulator shall:
(a)	Within five Business Days of receipt of the notice set out in Rule 3.2.2, and subject to Rule 3.2.5, provide notice of the intent to use the passporting procedures under these Rules to the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted; and
(b)	promptly following confirmation from the relevant Host Regulator that its respective Register of Passported Funds has been updated to include the details of the Passported Fund:
(i)	publish the details of the Passported Fund on the Register of Passported Funds; and
(ii)	notify the Fund Manager that registration on the Register of Passported Funds is complete.

target_text:

(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:

target_text:

(b)	if it considers that it is necessary and appropriate to refrain from doing so in order to meet its objectives.

question: In the context of an Exempt Offeror that wishes to voluntarily comply with the Listing Rules to include its Securities on the Official List and seek admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, what is the Regulator’s role in modifying chapter requirements, and how does that interact with the Recognised Investment Exchange’s prohibition on permitting trading unless the Securities are admitted to (and not suspended from) the Official List, including any stated exception?

Where an Issuer makes an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and therefore must publish a Prospectus, what defence is available to a person alleged to have contravened section 66(1) in relation to misleading or deceptive statements or omissions in that Prospectus, and what must be proven to rely on it?
source_text: Regulatory treatment of tokens deemed to be Securities. The requirements for Offers of Securities fall under Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules (“MKT”). When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, these requirements include, for example, the obligation to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR.

question: For purposes of determining whether the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement applies, how should an ADGM Green Portfolio treat an asset that qualifies as an Eligible Green Portfolio Asset because it is included in or otherwise tracks an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, and how does that compare to the taxonomy-based eligibility route that requires only one Acceptable Green Taxonomy to be used by an ADGM Green Portfolio?
source_text: Under Rule 3.8.6, the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets which are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark in accordance with Rule ‎3.8.4(b).

question: If an asset is treated as “Eligible” because it tracks an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, do you still need the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement, and what extra check applies when you instead rely on an Acceptable Green Taxonomy to make the asset eligible?
source_text: Under Rule 3.8.6, the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets which are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark in accordance with Rule ‎3.8.4(b).

question: When a Specified Benchmark is determined solely from information obtained from a market operated by a Recognised Body, a Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility, and the Benchmark Administrator for that Specified Benchmark is also that same entity, how may the Benchmark Administrator satisfy its obligation to develop rules and practice standards setting out responsibilities for Specified Benchmark Information Providers, other Persons providing information from outside the ADGM, and the Benchmark Administrator itself?

If a Specified Benchmark uses only information from a market run by a Recognised Body, a Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility, and that same entity is also the Benchmark Administrator, can it put its required rules and practice standards into the market’s own rules? What responsibilities still need to be covered?

Where an issue of, or agreement to issue, Securities was made without approval under Rule 9.7.1 but later receives holder approval, how should the Listed Entity determine whether those Securities are counted as approved or instead counted within Relevant Issues under Rule 9.7.1, including the effect of any lapse of approval and the three‑month issuance condition?

If a Listed Entity issues (or agrees to issue) Securities without Rule 9.7.1 approval, what has to happen for it to be treated as approved, and what changes if the approval under Rule 9.7.5 later lapses when you are counting it under Rule 9.7.1?

If an Authorised Person wants to use a Client’s Safe Custody Assets for itself or someone else, what must it do first and what proof has to be kept in the Resolution Pack, including any checks on Client Investments?

If an auditor or actuary breaks these Regulations, what can the Regulator do about stopping them from working for an Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity, and what things does the Regulator look at to decide how broad that ban should be?

Where an application concerns activities relating to Spot Commodities that will be carried on by a Recognised Body (whether a Recognised Investment Exchange or Recognised Clearing House), how should the applicant determine the applicable application fee when the applicant is also an Applicant for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Principal (but not as a Matched Principal)?

If an application is about Spot Commodities activities that will be carried on by a Recognised Body (a Recognised Investment Exchange or Recognised Clearing House), and the same applicant is also applying for Financial Services Permission to deal in investments as principal (not as a matched principal), what fee information do they need to use from each passage to work out what they must pay?

Where a Relevant Person is maintaining the record categories listed for CDD/due diligence, transaction reconstruction, suspicious activity notifications/reports, FIU communications, and other required matters for the stated retention period, may those records be kept electronically, and what accessibility standard applies when the Regulator requests information?

When the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund (or the governing body or trustee) notifies the Regulator of a material event—such as an amended Prospectus or the commencement of winding-up—what subsequent notification must the Regulator make, and what timing standard applies to that onward notification, given the Regulator’s duty upon receiving a notification described in Rule 6.6.2?

When a Third Party Provider is required to make dispute resolution service details available to the Customer in a clear, comprehensive and easily accessible form, through which specific channels must that information be made available, given the Rule 20.13.3 availability locations?
If a Customer asks where they can find the dispute resolution service details, what places does the Third Party Provider have to put that information so it is easy to access?

For an SFT in which both the Exposure and the Collateral are Securities issued by central governments, when may an Authorised Person set HE, HC and HS to zero, and how does the required risk-weighting for a CR Exposure in the central government and central bank asset class (including the Credit Quality Grade 1 outcome) support that determination?

If an Authorised Person has an SFT where both the Exposure and the Collateral are central government Securities, what exact conditions must be true to use zero for HE, HC and HS, and what does the central government/central bank risk-weight table say about Credit Quality Grade 1 that links to that choice?

If a Payment Service Provider intends to amend the Framework Contract’s disclosure of charges payable by the Payment Service User (including any breakdown of amounts), what is the minimum advance notice period for providing that proposed amendment to the Payment Service User, and why does that charges disclosure qualify as information whose change triggers the notice requirement?

When a Recognised Clearing House determines whether it holds capital at least equal to the required sum of risk-based components, how must it source and treat the operational-expense figures used for (i) the six months’ gross operational expenses element and (ii) the minimum floor tied to annual gross operational expenses for business risk?

In calculating the capital sum a Recognised Clearing House must hold, how do the operational-expense inputs used for the winding-down/restructuring component interact with the business-risk minimum, and what specific source and accounting basis must be applied to those operational-expense inputs?
If a reconciliation is done under Rule 15.9.1, who has to review it, and what written statement must the individual referred to in Rule 15.9.4 provide about how the reconciliation was done?

If a Listed Entity wants to issue Shares with Weighted Voting Rights, what does it need to do about Regulator approval, and how does the Board’s rule about treating holders of the same class or type of Securities equally fit with the fact that weighted voting changes voting power and equity interest?

When an Authorised Person is considering recognising the effects of CRM for a guarantee provided by an MDB, what condition must be met for the guarantee to be eligible for CRM recognition, and how must the Authorised Person risk-weight any CR Exposure to a qualifying MDB such as the Asian Development Bank (ADB)?

If a guarantee is provided by a member of The World Bank Group, how should an Authorised Person determine (i) whether the guarantee’s CRM effects may be recognised and (ii) whether a 0% risk weight applies to a CR Exposure to that institution, taking into account that The World Bank Group includes IBRD, MIGA, and IFC?

Where a Recognised Investment Exchange’s Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to operate an MTF, how should the Recognised Investment Exchange determine which rulebook applies to (i) the MTF function when it is operated using Virtual Assets and (ii) the remainder of its operations, given that COBS applies to the MTF/OTF function only?

If a Recognised Investment Exchange is allowed by its Recognition Order to run an MTF, what rules apply to the MTF part (especially if it uses Virtual Assets) and what rules apply to everything else it does?

Before publishing a financing proposal for a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, what due diligence must a PFP Operator carry out to support the disclosure requirements, and what records of that due diligence and related materials must the PFP Operator retain (and for how long)?

If an Authorised Person runs an MTF for Virtual Assets, what MIR Chapter 5 rules do they have to follow, and what extra point does COBS Rule 17.7.4 make about notifications/information and paragraph 29 on additional Accepted Virtual Assets?

When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 that includes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, how should it structure the required assumptions and Production Target content so that the overall disclosure also meets the “fair and balanced” representation expectation for information drawn from a separate report annexed under Rule 11.6.2, without attempting to summarise the entire annexure?
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: If a Passported Fund’s Fund Manager becomes aware that the Prospectus has been amended or replaced, how quickly does it have to tell the Regulator, and what information and documents must be included with that notice?

When seeking to have an investment treated as a Security for an Offer of Digital Securities to the public, what specific submission does the FSRA indicate it will review as key to deciding whether it can use its deeming power, and how does that relate to the Regulator’s ability to deem a non-Security to be a Security by written notice (including any conditions)?

If you want the Regulator to treat something that is not a Security as a Security, what document information does the FSRA say it needs for an Offer of Digital Securities, and what form can the Regulator use to do the deeming (and with what kind of extra conditions)?

When applying the Chapter’s requirement to recognise and measure an Insurer’s assets and liabilities using the basis of accounting referenced in Rule 5.3.2, which accounting standards must the Insurer adopt for the purposes of Rule 5.3.1, and how does that differ for a Takaful Insurer versus any other Insurer?

If an Insurer is measuring and recording its assets and liabilities under the Chapter using the basis of accounting in Rule 5.3.2, what accounting standards does it have to use for Rule 5.3.1 if it is (1) a Takaful Insurer or (2) not a Takaful Insurer?

When an Authorised Person prepares or publishes Investment Research and identifies an actual or potential conflict of interest, what form and level of detail must any conflict disclosure have so that the relevant Client can make an informed decision in the context of the service?

Where an Offer in or from the ADGM is structured so that different tranches rely on different prescribed Exempt Offer circumstances (e.g., one tranche directed at no more than 50 Persons in a 12-month period and another tranche meeting a $100,000 minimum consideration threshold), under what condition can the Offer still be treated as an Exempt Offer notwithstanding that it falls partly within more than one circumstance?

For Securities admitted to trading on an MTF under an Exempt Offer, what combined arrangements are required to ensure users can access information (including Offer documents and Inside Information) while also meeting the Recognised Investment Exchange obligation to assist users in obtaining access to information made public under disclosure obligations?

For a Third Party Provider’s Governing Contract, how should the contract’s required exchange-rate disclosures and any agreed approach to changing exchange rates be structured so that the provider can apply exchange-rate changes immediately and without notice only in the permitted cases?

If a Third Party Provider wants to change exchange rates right away without telling the Customer first, what must be written into the Governing Contract about exchange rates and Reference Exchange Rates, and when is the “no notice” change allowed?

If someone is worried that a message they send could count as an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market, what changes if the Regulator has prescribed that kind of message as an Exempt Communication under section 59(c) of the FSMR, given the Regulations’ ban on making an Offer of Securities (and on admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange)?
If you’re working out an Authorised Person’s Leverage Ratio, what do you add up to get the Tier 1 Capital used in the Capital Measure, and what do you divide it by?

Where a person has failed to comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR and is certified in default, what must the Court of First Instance be satisfied about before it may treat the Defaulter as if in contempt, and who else may be dealt with in that way if the Defaulter is a Body Corporate?

If someone doesn’t follow a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR and gets certified in default, what does the Court of First Instance need to believe before treating them like they’re in contempt, and if the Defaulter is a Body Corporate, who else can the Court treat that way?

If a Host Regulator asks the Regulator to do an on-site inspection about a Passported Fund, what is the normal response, and when is the Regulator allowed to say no because there is already enforcement action or a court case about the same conduct and the same Persons?

When an Applicant is seeking admission of Shares to the Official List, how should the Applicant frame its demonstration to the Regulator that it (and any Subsidiaries) has sufficient working capital for its present requirements, including the relevant time horizon the Regulator uses for assessing those present requirements and what must be addressed if working capital is not sufficient?

If a company applies to list Shares, what does it need to show the Regulator about working capital for itself and any Subsidiaries, and over what time period does the Regulator treat “present requirements” as covering from the admission date?

If a Mining Production Reporting Entity is doing its quarterly report and needs to cover the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months (unless it’s in the annual report), what must it say about the timing of the last and next Summary disclosure, and how recent must the date be for the MKT Form 11-1 table inside that Summary?

When designing the strategy’s system for controlling Liquidity Risk that enables the Authorised Person to implement the requirements in Rule 9.2.6, what specific capabilities and governance/approval features must that system include for the Authorised Person’s Governing Body and senior management, including in relation to limits set under Rule 9.2.7 and operating procedures?

If the strategy has to include a system for controlling Liquidity Risk so the Authorised Person can carry out Rule 9.2.6, what does that system need to let the Governing Body and senior management do, and what kinds of approval/limit controls must it have (including around limits set under Rule 9.2.7 and operating procedures)?

If an Authorised Person has foreign currency and gold risk under an Islamic Contract, can it ever skip calculating the Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement? If yes, what numbers does it have to check and how are they measured?

When an Authorised Person chooses to reduce the value of its Exposures using Collateral, how must it determine the Collateral amount to recognise if the Collateral’s value under a stress scenario is below the value otherwise applied under Rule 4.15.12 for purposes of this Section?

If an Authorised Person decides to lower its Exposures using Collateral, what value should it use for the Collateral when the stress-scenario value is lower than the value it would otherwise use under Rule 4.15.12?

How must an Authorised Person align its systems-and-controls responsibilities for operating and monitoring a Spot Commodity Auction Platform with the participant safeguards that require transparent rules, transaction recording, information availability, and measures against Market Abuse or Financial Crime?

When an Authorised Person is responsible for the full technical operation of a Spot Commodity Auction Platform (including contingency arrangements for disruption), what participant-protection outcomes must its rules, procedures, and related arrangements deliver regarding auctions, execution criteria, settlement/title transfer, information availability, transaction recording, and fee transparency?

If an Authorised Person submits a Regulatory Filing after it becomes due, what are the compliance consequences, including the specific late payment fee amount and any additional regulatory response beyond the fee?

If an Authorised Person is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, and it also has a Large Exposure in its Non Trading Book (or Trading Book), what percentage limits apply, and what do those limits get measured against (Tier 1 vs Capital Resources) including when the PSIA limit can be 25% or 40%?

Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, how may the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider contractually modify the rule on withdrawal of consent for an individual Payment Transaction, and how does that modification interact with the point in time tied to revocation under Rule 19.14.3?

If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, can the parties agree in writing that the usual withdrawal-of-consent rule does not apply, and what is the time limit for withdrawing consent in the rule that links it to revocation under Rule 19.14.3?

Where Confidential Information is sought for use as evidence in civil litigation by a party other than a governmental or regulatory authority, what consents are required before the Regulator may permit disclosure, and how do those consents align with the consent requirements imposed on a primary recipient (and downstream recipients) before any disclosure can occur?

If someone wants Confidential Information for a civil court case (not a government or regulator request), who has to say “yes” before it can be shared, and does the same “two-consent” idea apply when the information is held by a primary recipient or someone who got it from them?

When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation and relies on the carve-out from Rule 11.2.1(1), what specific disclosures must it include in its Summary of Reserves and Resources if it has previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates under Rule 11.7.3 that have not later been disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, including the additional disclosures triggered after three years from first disclosure under Rule 11.7.4?

Under what conditions may a letter of credit be treated as a qualifying letter of credit and included as eligible capital, and what specific characteristics must the instrument and issuing bank have to satisfy the referenced Rule 3.1.4(2) requirements?
When can a letter of credit count as eligible capital as a “qualifying letter of credit”? List what the Regulator must do and the key features the letter of credit and the bank must have.

When an Authorised Person conducts a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, how must references to “Client Investments” in GEN be interpreted, and what is the practical compliance effect of that interpretation on the scope of FSRA Rulebook provisions (including any specific COBS chapters identified) that use the term “Client Investments”?

If an Authorised Person is doing a Regulated Activity involving Virtual Assets, what should they treat “Client Investments” in GEN as meaning, and how does that change which FSRA Rulebook rules (including any named COBS chapters) apply to Virtual Assets?

If a Third Party Provider wants to change what the Governing Contract says about charges (like the details of all charges payable by the Customer), how early does it have to send the proposed change to the Customer before it starts?

When an Authorised Person is applying the arrears-day thresholds for classifying Exposures (special mention, substandard, doubtful, loss), how must the Authorised Person ensure that any Evergreening exercise involving refinancing of past due credits does not inappropriately improve the classification category, including for impaired credits?

If a loan is past due and you are classifying it based on how many days it is in arrears (30, 60, 90–120, 120–180), what should you do if the credit is refinanced as part of an Evergreening exercise—can that refinancing move it into a better category, especially if it is impaired?

When the Regulator is considering whether to give a direction to a Recognised Body in matters relating to its Controllers to advance one or more operational objectives, what information and factors must the Regulator take into account in deciding whether it is appropriate to exercise its direction-giving powers under Rule 6.6.1 or Rule 6.7.2?

If the Regulator wants to direct a Recognised Body about its Controllers because it thinks the direction would help meet one or more operational objectives, what should it look at before deciding it is appropriate to use its direction powers under Rule 6.6.1 or Rule 6.7.2?

For an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, how must GEN Rule 5.2.14 be applied and interpreted, and how does that interpretation fit within the broader set of rulebooks and additional requirements that the Authorised Person must comply with (including the scenario where it is also Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets)?

If an Authorised Person uses the FCSA and has eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure, what numbers does it plug into the RWA(CR) = E x CRW formula for the secured part and the unsecured part, and how does that fit into the overall process for calculating total RWA for CR Exposures?

When the Investigator issues a written notice requiring production of Specified Documents at a Specified time and place, what forms of documents may be demanded and what authority does the Investigator have to keep originals after production?

If the Investigator requires a person (including someone not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to permit entry to business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy Documents, how does that interact with the Investigator’s power to require production of specified documents, including originals or copies and retention of originals?

If a Person applies for an ADGM Green Bond (or any other designation in the list), what fee do they pay when applying, and what fee do they pay later if the Regulator grants the designation (including how the first year is handled and when later years are due)?

For Units already admitted to trading on another Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange (the Other Market), what specific conditions must be met to use the section 61 FSMR exemption for admission to trading, and what overarching requirement applies to the trading of all Units in the class (including those specified under Rule 3.3.5) once admitted?

If a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure about Non-Equivalent Estimates, what does it need to do in a later update so it doesn’t have to repeat the Rule 11.7.3 information, and how does that fit with the rule that lets it skip Rule 11.2.1(1) for material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation?

Where a Recognised Investment Exchange is permitted by the FSRA (and within the scope of its Recognition Order) to operate a separate MTF, OTF and/or MTF using Virtual Assets, what additional market must it also operate, and how do the Recognition Requirements apply in that combined operating model?

Where the parties have agreed that Rule 19.11.1(3) does not apply because a Low Value Payment Instrument does not allow for the stopping or prevention of its use, what ongoing capability must the Payment Service Provider still maintain for Payment Service Users regarding reporting loss, theft, misappropriation, or unauthorised use of the Payment Instrument?

If a Low Value Payment Instrument can’t be stopped and the parties agree that the rule about notifying loss (Rule 19.11.1(3)) doesn’t apply, does the Payment Service Provider still need to keep a way for users to report loss or unauthorised use at any time? What exactly has to be available?

Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and is using the FCCA, how should the firm determine and apply E* in the credit risk weighted exposure calculation, and what haircut methodology options are available when calculating E* for such a collateralised transaction (other than an OTC Derivative transaction or a long settlement transaction)?

When calculating RWA for securitisation Exposures, how must an Authorised Person use the Exposure measurement methodology, and how does that methodology’s stated purpose (covering both Credit RWA for Credit Risk Exposures under Rule 4.8.3 and securitisation Exposures under Rule 4.8.4) connect to the step in which the Exposure value is determined under Section 4.9?

If an Authorised Person is working out RWA for securitisation Exposures, what are the main steps they must follow, and how does the Exposure measurement methodology’s stated role for both Credit Risk (Rule 4.8.3) and securitisation (Rule 4.8.4) explain why they start by measuring the Exposure under Section 4.9?

Where a RIE settles Digital Securities without engaging a RCH and instead uses a DSF, what written confirmation must the RIE provide to the FSRA/Regulator about its arrangements, and what additional compliance condition is imposed on the DSF in that scenario?

If a Recognised Investment Exchange uses a Digital Settlement Facility (DSF) to settle Digital Securities instead of using a Recognised Clearing House, what does it need to send in writing to the Regulator/FSRA, and what rule does the DSF have to meet (with any needed wording change)?

When an Authorised Person acts as a clearing member intermediary between a client and a CCP, how should it determine the exposure measure it uses to calculate Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to that client, and when would a different method be permitted for derivatives or long settlement transactions?

If an Authorised Person is a clearing member between a client and a CCP, what does it have to do to work out Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to the client, and how does the EAD rule for derivatives/long settlement deals change if the Regulator allows an internal model?

How should a Third Party Provider demonstrate that its professional indemnity insurance is sufficient to reimburse Customers for operational risk events while also complying with the Transaction Limits requirement tied to the average daily value of Third Party Transactions over the past ninety calendar days?

If a Third Party Provider wants to be sure customers can be repaid after an operational risk event, what insurance level must it keep when you also factor in the rule that compares remaining coverage to the last 90 days of Third Party Transactions?

What capabilities must a Recognised Investment Exchange have to determine whether a participant or Member has exceeded a position limit set for a Derivative or class of Derivatives, and what specific categories of positions must it include in that determination (including any Derivative-equivalent treatment for Options)?

If a Recognised Investment Exchange is checking whether a participant or Member has gone over a position limit for a Derivative (or a class of Derivatives), what must the exchange be able to do, and whose positions does it need to count—including how it should treat Options on the Derivative?

When an Authorised Person calculates the Exposure value for SFTs as on-balance sheet items using IFRS and the applicable netting requirements, what must it be able to demonstrate to the Regulator is in place for netting to be recognised, including the legal and procedural elements and the failure events covered?

If an Authorised Person is working out the Exposure value for on-balance sheet SFTs using IFRS and netting, what paperwork and ongoing checks does it need so it can prove to the Regulator that netting is valid, and in what counterparty failure situations does the net amount apply?

When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 that includes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, how must it address (i) the material economic assumptions (including any claim of commercial sensitivity) and (ii) the need to disclose key underlying assumptions and outcomes from a relevant Technical Study used to support confidence in modifying factors for Ore Reserves?
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity publishes forecast financial information based on a Production Target, what details does it need to include about its assumptions (including if it says they are commercially sensitive), and what extra Technical Study information must also be disclosed to support confidence in modifying factors for Ore Reserves?

question: If a Payment Order for one Payment Transaction is sent using a Payment Instrument under a Framework Contract, what information can the Payment Service Provider skip because another Payment Service Provider covers it under Section 19.2, and what information must still be given right after the Payment Order is initiated?

When a Prospectus by a Mining Reporting Entity contains a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, what preparation standards and additional content must be met, including any cross-referenced rule and sustainability-related disclosures?

If a Mining Reporting Entity’s Prospectus talks about Exploration Targets (or similar items like Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves), what rules does it have to follow to prepare that disclosure, and what extra sustainability information has to be included in the Prospectus?

Where a Recognised Clearing House makes provision as allowed under Rule 4.5.8, how must its procedures address (i) the designation and ongoing review of Persons or descriptions of person and (ii) the substantive market-operation risk test that determines whether a Person or description should not be, or should not remain, designated?

If the Recognised Clearing House uses the option allowed under Rule 4.5.8, what should its procedures cover for choosing and removing designated Persons (or descriptions of person), and what market-impact check must those procedures be designed to apply about failures to meet obligations under one or more Market Contracts?

When the Regulator receives the notice referred to in Rule 3.1.2 and is considering whether to send the notice of intent to use passporting procedures to Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days, in what circumstances must it refrain from transmitting the notice under Rule 3.1.4(a), and what downstream steps (including publication and notification) are tied to Host Regulator confirmation if the process proceeds?

When the Regulator is considering granting a waiver from Rule 3.5.1 for an order on a Recognised Investment Exchange market on the basis that it is “large in scale compared with normal market size,” what specific threshold and classification method must be used to determine whether the order qualifies?

If someone wants a waiver from Rule 3.5.1 because an order is “large in scale,” how do you decide if it is big enough, and what extra step applies to Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange market?

When FSRA assesses whether a Spot Commodity Settlement Facility (SCSF) has satisfactory arrangements to secure timely discharge of parties’ rights and liabilities under MIR Rule 4.3.3, how should that assessment be reconciled with the statement that a Recognised Clearing House is not treated as breaching its Recognition Requirement solely because it cannot arrange settlement of a specific transaction?

If a Relevant Person wants to use a Person in (1) to do parts of CDD, what checks does it need to do about the other country’s AML/TFS rules being FATF-equivalent, and what must it get right away from the third party?

Where an Offer is directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients (and the Securities are offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility), how does this interact with an Issuer’s ability to make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients when the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF?

Where an Authorised Person is (i) under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4 and operates as a Cell Company and (ii) also holds a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, what annual supervision fees must be paid to the Regulator, and how does the number of Cells affect the total?

If an Authorised Person runs a Cell Company (under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4) and also has permission to do insurance business as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, what yearly supervision fees does it owe, and what part changes when it adds more Cells?

Under this Part, what conduct is prohibited when a person provides information “in purported compliance,” and how does the non-compliance discussion extend beyond false or misleading information to cover obstruction of investigative powers (including examples)?

When a Recognised Investment Exchange is drafting Business Rules to admit Units in an open-ended Collective Investment Fund to trading, how should it operationalise the requirement that instruments be capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner, and which specific fund-related factors must it assess for that purpose?

If an Issuer is offering Securities to the public in or from ADGM and needs to publish a Prospectus, what can the Regulator do if the person making the Prospectus Offer doesn’t publish required information, and where do the Prospectus obligations come from?

When considering whether to modify or waive Rule 2.3.2 for an admission to the Official List, how should the Regulator assess whether investors have the necessary information, specifically in relation to the Applicant’s audited financial statements (including period covered, consolidation, accounting standards, and audit standards)?

If the Regulator is thinking about waiving or changing Rule 2.3.2 for a company seeking admission to the Official List, what audited accounts information should be checked to help show investors can still make an informed judgement about the Issuer and the Shares?

If you are working out what goes into an Authorised Person’s Available Stable Funding (ASF), and you see AT1 Capital items, what exactly counts as AT1 Capital (including share premium), and what extra ASF screening step must you apply for Tier 2 instruments with short remaining maturity?

Where a PFP Operator updates information it has published under Rule 18.5.1 to reflect a material change and provides notice of that change to PFP Clients, what specific records must it retain and for how long, including any related transaction documentation and due diligence materials?

If a PFP Operator makes a material change to the information it publishes under Rule 18.5.1, what does it need to do for PFP Clients, and what records does it have to keep (and for how long) to show it did this and handled the related work?

If an Appointed auditor thinks a company might not be a going concern or can’t make certain statements in the audit report, what does the Recognised Body need to have in place so the auditor can notify the Regulator, and how does that connect to the general rule about telling the Regulator about likely breaches of Regulations or Rules?

Under a Framework Contract, when the Customer is not a Natural Person, can the Customer and the Third Party Provider agree in writing to disapply the prohibition on charging for information required under Section 20.2, and what form and scope must that agreement take?

If the Customer is a company (not a Natural Person), can the Customer and the Third Party Provider put in writing that the Third Party Provider may charge for information that Section 20.2 says must be provided under a Framework Contract?

For an Authorised Person that falls within Category 1, 2, 3A or 5, how should it determine the frequency for calculating its NSFR so that it can monitor ongoing compliance and respond to potential material changes in its funding profile?
If an Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5, when does it need to calculate its NSFR, and what kinds of changes should make it run the calculation again?

How should an Authorised Person determine whether its Dealing in Investments as Principal activity keeps it in Category 2 or instead places it within Category 3A, where the firm asserts it acts only as a Matched Principal and holds residual positions? In your answer, include the specific conditions that must be met for the firm to be treated as dealing as a Matched Principal and explain how that interacts with the Category 2 guidance about dealing authorisation.
source_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: Where the Customer is not a Natural Person, how may the Customer and the Third Party Provider contractually modify the withdrawal-of-consent regime for an individual Third Party Transaction, and how does that interact with the revocation point referenced for such withdrawals?

If the Customer is not a Natural Person, can the Customer and the Third Party Provider agree in writing that the usual consent-withdrawal rules do not apply, and if so, when can the Customer withdraw consent for one Third Party Transaction (based on the revocation point mentioned)?

When an MTF or OTF uses arrangements to make information public (including trading information required under MIR Rules 3.5 and 3.6), what conditions must those arrangements meet, and how does the requirement for a consistent and structured format relate to the ability of Recognised Investment Exchanges to choose the structure used?

If an MTF or OTF is publishing trading information to the public, what practical checks must its publishing setup meet (reliability, monitoring, and equal access), and what does “consistent and structured format” mean in light of the note that Recognised Investment Exchanges can pick the structure they use?

Where an Applicant/Authorised Person will undertake a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets in addition to Virtual Assets and therefore must seek FSRA approval for both asset types, how should the firm assess whether fees for the two categories could be charged cumulatively, and what discretion does the Regulator have to reduce, waive, or refund fees (including supplementary or late payment fees) in that context?
target_text:
Relief from Payment
The Regulator may at any time reduce, waive or refund all or part of any fee including any supplementary or late payment fee if it considers that, in the circumstances of a particular case, it would be fair and reasonable to do so.

question: If an Authorised Person wants to count financial collateral, what are the two allowed methods it can use, and if it picks the FCCA method, what kinds of collateral count (including the extra rules for fund Units)?
target_text:
For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises:
(a)	any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5;
(b)	any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and
(c)	any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where:
(i)	a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and
(ii)	at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: For an Authorised Person that is Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets, how do the minimum frequencies for (i) sending the COBS Rule 15.8.1(a) statements to a Retail Client and (ii) conducting reconciliations compare with the separate requirement to reconcile Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents to monthly statements from those Third Party Agents?

If an Authorised Person is Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets, how often do they need to (1) send the required statement to a Retail Client, (2) do the COBS Rule 15.9.1 reconciliations, and (3) reconcile Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents to the monthly statements from those agents?

When the Regulator is considering disclosing Confidential Information to a criminal law enforcement agency (in the U.A.E or otherwise) for the purpose of a criminal investigation or criminal proceedings under paragraph 199(1)(b)(v), do the prior written consent conditions that apply to other disclosure gateways (including where the information originates from another authority or is CRD Information) need to be satisfied?

When determining the risk weight for a CR Exposure, how should an Authorised Person treat an exposure that is categorised as a cash item but is specifically a cheque, draft, or other item drawn on another banking institution that is payable immediately upon presentation or is in the process of collection?

When an Authorised Person (and its participants) proposes to use a delivery and/or storage facility for Accepted Spot Commodities from outside the ADGM, what jurisdictional limitation applies and what specific facility-level conditions must be satisfied for that facility to be acceptable for the purposes of Rule 22.4.1?

Where an Authorised Person operating an MTF or OTF wishes to also operate a RIE, what must happen to its FSP upon obtaining a Recognition Order, and how does the Recognition Order’s stipulation affect (i) whether the RIE may operate the MTF/OTF and (ii) which rulebook provisions apply to that MTF/OTF function?

This section applies to the Board of a Listed Entity and to each individual Director on that Board. If the section talks about “Shareholders” but the people voting are Debenture holders on a change to their rights or terms, who should be treated as “Shareholders,” and what extra rule checks is the Regulator expecting?

When an Authorised Person is using the FCCA and wants to recognise the effects of CRM by taking eligible financial Collateral, what must the Authorised Person do in relation to Rule 4.13.8, and which types of Collateral qualify as eligible financial Collateral (including any conditions that apply to Units in a Collective Investment Fund)?
source_text:
Collateral
In order to recognise the effects of CRM of the types of Collateral set out in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, an Authorised Person must ensure that the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are complied with.

target_text: Systems and controls for the use of securitisations. An Authorised Person must conduct periodic stress tests in relation to its securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, including testing of future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 that includes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, how should it handle material economic assumptions it considers commercially sensitive, and what level of summary is still expected when commercially sensitive information is withheld?
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: When assessing whether information qualifies as “Inside Information” for instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives, how should a firm apply the “significant effect on price” limb across Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities, and Related Instruments, given that the definition is stated in section 95(2)?

Where the Board of a Listed Entity is convening a meeting for holders of Debentures to vote on a variation of rights or terms, how should the proxy-voting obligation for meetings of “Shareholders” be applied, and what additional rule-context must the Person referred to in Rule 9.3.1 take into account when treating those Debenture holders as the relevant voting constituency?

If an Authorised Person is adding up its Credit RWA, what steps does it follow to work out the part for its securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures), and how does that part connect to Early Amortisation Exposures?
