For an Authorised Person that is a Payment Account Provider and has a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services, how must it determine its Capital Requirement, and how is the Variable Capital Requirement component calculated using monthly payment volume tiers?

If an Authorised Person is a Payment Account Provider under Providing Money Services, what numbers does it compare to set its Capital Requirement, and how do you work out the Variable Capital Requirement from monthly payment volume?

When the Regulator acts on its own initiative against an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission, what specific circumstances can trigger use of the power, and what range of outcomes (including partial changes versus full cancellation) may the Regulator impose on the Financial Services Permission?

If an Authorised Person hasn’t carried on a Regulated Activity for at least 12 months, what can the Regulator do to the Financial Services Permission on its own initiative, and what limits apply if it changes the description of a Regulated Activity?

When an Authorised Person (and its participants) selects a delivery and/or storage facility for Accepted Spot Commodities from an appropriate jurisdiction outside the ADGM, what specific facility-level conditions must be satisfied to meet the Rule 22.4.2 standard referenced by the location restriction?

If an Authorised Person wants to use a delivery and/or storage facility for Accepted Spot Commodities that is not in the ADGM, what does the facility need to have or follow so the place counts as an “appropriate jurisdiction” under the rule?

Where an Applicant for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services will conduct both of the activities referenced in Rule 3.9.1, how should the Applicant determine the application fee payable to the Regulator, given the activity-based fee table for Currency exchange or Money Remittance and for Payment Services?

If an Applicant is applying for permission to provide money services and plans to do both activities mentioned in Rule 3.9.1, what application fee do they pay, and how does that relate to the table that lists fees for “Currency exchange or Money Remittance” and “Payment Services”?

When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, how do the preparation requirements interact with the scope of materials covered and the expectation to use a specific table format for consistency?

For an Issuer making an Exempt Offer of a Digital Security, how do the requirements that the Digital Security be deemed a Security under Section 58(2)(b) of FSMR and the Regulator’s power to deem an investment to be a Security interact, and does the Issuer need FSRA approval for the Exempt Offer document itself?

If an Issuer is doing an Exempt Offer of a Digital Security, do they still need the Digital Security to count as a Security, and how could the Regulator’s written notice power help with that? Also, do they need FSRA approval for the Exempt Offer document?

Where a Payment Service Provider proposes to change the exchange rate used in Payment Transactions under a Framework Contract, what implementation standard applies to that exchange-rate change and what is the minimum advance notice period for providing the change to the Payment Service User before it takes effect?

If the exchange rate used in Payment Transactions is going to change, what does “neutral and non-discriminatory” mean for how it’s applied, and how long before the change starts does the Payment Service Provider have to tell the Payment Service User?

If one person breaks the rules and another person is Knowingly Concerned, who can be treated as having committed the contravention, and what does that mean for a contravention of FSMR or Rules compared with a contravention of these Regulations?

When applying the formula-based restriction on new Issues of Equity Securities, how must a Listed Entity treat Securities whose approval under Rule 9.7.5 has lapsed when determining whether the issue would exceed the “Maximum number of Equity Securities” without holder approval, and which component(s) of the calculation are affected?

If a Listed Entity is working out how many Equity Securities it can issue without getting approval from holders of Ordinary Securities, what happens in the calculation if an earlier approval under Rule 9.7.5 has lapsed?

When calculating CET1 Capital, how must an Authorised Person treat (i) Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips (net of the deductions from CET1 Capital required at Rule 4.14.13) and (ii) any increase in issued capital or reserves resulting from a securitisation (including gain-on-sale amounts tied to expected future margin income), and how do these treatments interact in the CET1 deduction calculation?

If an Authorised Person has a securitisation that creates a gain on sale (from expected future margin income) recorded in issued capital or reserves, and it also holds Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips, what exactly has to be deducted from CET1 Capital and at what rate for the strips (taking into account the “net of Rule 4.14.13 deductions” wording)?

If an Authorised Person has a CR Exposure to a central government or central bank of a GCC member country (including an individual Emirate of the UAE treated as a GCC member country), and the exposure is not denominated and funded in that domestic currency, how must the exposure be treated and can a 0% risk weight still be applied?

For an Authorised Person that is a Virtual Asset Custodian, how does the requirement to treat “Client Assets” and “Client Investments” as including “Virtual Assets” affect the minimum technology governance systems and controls that must be implemented for Virtual Asset Wallets, keys, transaction origin/destination, security, and risk management?

If an Authorised Person is holding Virtual Assets for clients, what does it mean that “Client Assets” and “Client Investments” must be read to include “Virtual Assets,” and what minimum systems and controls must the firm have for wallets, keys, tracking where funds come from/go to, security, and risk management?

When preparing the quarterly report disclosure that must include (at least once every 12 months) the Summary of Reserves and Resources, what specific table format and “as of” date constraint must the Mining Reporting Entity apply to that Summary, and how does that constraint relate to the timing of the quarterly report’s disclosure of when the previous and upcoming Summary will be made?

In the quarterly report, the Mining Exploration Reporting Entity has to include a Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months (unless it’s in the annual report) and say when the last and next Summary will be disclosed. What table has to be inside that Summary, and how recent does the table’s “as of” date have to be compared with the Summary’s disclosure date?

If a Mining Reporting Entity shares forecast financial information based on a Production Target and also includes an Ore Reserves estimate, what details do they need to add about assumptions for the forecast and what extra technical details must be included for the Ore Reserves part (including what to do if the economic assumptions are commercially sensitive)?
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: When the Regulator is assessing an application for a Financial Services Permission to Operate a Multilateral Trading Facility, how should the applicant treat the TARGET’s references to “Investment” if the applicant is an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, and how does that affect the way the applicant addresses the Regulator’s stated assessment matters?

If an Authorised Person wants permission to run a Multilateral Trading Facility for Virtual Assets, what should they do with the word “Investment” in the Regulator’s application checks, and what are the main checks they still need to cover?

If an Authorised Person uses a legally valid bilateral netting agreement that turns many gross amounts into one net payable/receivable amount, how does that connect to the way Exposure value must be worked out for on-balance sheet SFTs?

For a Preference Security that is not a Share, how must the terms of issue frame the Security holder’s voting rights so that they follow the Rule 9.3.10 voting mechanics (with necessary adaptation to the instrument’s form) while also limiting entitlement to vote to the specific circumstances listed for Preference Securities?

If a company issues a Preference Security that is not a Share, what should the terms say about how the holder votes (using the Rule 9.3.10 approach, adapted to the security’s form) and when the holder is allowed to vote (only in the listed situations)?

When the Third Party Provider intends to change exchange rates under the Governing Contract, how do the notice timing requirements interact with the circumstances in which exchange-rate changes may be applied immediately and without notice, including any dependency on Reference Exchange Rate information provided under Rule 20.2.2?

If the Third Party Provider wants to change something in the Governing Contract, when do they have to tell the Customer, and when can an exchange-rate change happen right away without notice (including any link to Reference Exchange Rate information under Rule 20.2.2)?

If you’re working out risk for a Derivative transaction and it’s also an on-balance sheet item, what numbers do you add up for the exposure value, and when do you have to use SA-CCR to calculate EAD instead of another method?

When applying Rule 4.12.19 to determine whether an Exposure (other than those referred to in Rule 4.12.20) is associated with particularly high risks, how must an Authorised Person combine the risk-characteristic assessment with the rule’s mandatory inclusion of certain Investments (e.g., venture capital funds, hedge funds/alternative investment funds, speculative immovable property financing, or Investments declared high risk by the Regulator)?

If you are an Authorised Person and you are checking whether something counts as an Exposure with particularly high risks under Rule 4.12.19, what do you do when it is (i) an Investment like a venture capital fund or hedge fund, versus (ii) another Exposure (not one of the Exposures referred to in Rule 4.12.20) where you are unsure how risky it is?

If a Listed Entity already made an issue (or agreement) without approval, what has to happen for it to be treated as approved later, and why does that matter when working out the “Maximum number of Equity Securities” using the 20% formula and the “Relevant Issues” subtraction?

Where the Customer is not a Natural Person and the Customer and the Third Party Provider agree in writing to disapply Rule 20.11.1, how does that agreement affect the allocation of the burden of proof when the Customer denies authorising an executed Third Party Transaction or alleges incorrect execution, and what elements must the Third Party Provider otherwise be able to demonstrate?

If the Customer is not a Natural Person, can the Customer and the Third Party Provider agree in writing to switch off the rule about evidence on authentication and execution, and if they do not switch it off, what does the Third Party Provider have to prove when the Customer says a Third Party Transaction was not authorised or was executed wrongly?

During the term of a Framework Contract, if the Payment Service User asks the Payment Service Provider for the contractual information, what must the Payment Service Provider provide, and how does that request relate to the specific categories of information that the Framework Contract must include (including, for example, the Payment Service Provider’s ADGM office contact details and the cut-off time for processing a Payment Order)?

When an Authorised Person is an MTF Operator or OTF Operator and is required to comply with specified MIR provisions by reading Recognised Body/RIE references as applying to the operator, how should the operator interpret any MIR terms that appear via MIR being incorporated into COBS Chapter 8 for the purposes of Rule 17.7.2—specifically where those incorporated provisions use the terms “Investment(s)” or “Financial Instrument(s)”?

For an Authorised Person underwriting an issue of Securities, how must the commencement of the initial underwriting commitment be determined when the Authorised Person has, at its discretion, an irrevocable right to withdraw from the Underwriting commitment that is exercisable for a specified period (and the commitment is otherwise treated as subject to any right set out in Rule 5.10.6)?

Where an Issuer is seeking to issue Digital Securities and is preparing its application for listing, how does the FSRA’s stated expectation that the working capital statement requirement applies under MKT Rule 2.3.3 align with the Regulator’s requirement for an Applicant seeking admission of Shares to the Official List to demonstrate sufficient working capital (including for any Subsidiaries), and what must be addressed if working capital is not sufficient?

If an Issuer wants to issue Digital Securities and is applying to list, what does it need to cover about working capital in its working capital statement, and what should it say if it does not have enough—especially given the rule about an Applicant seeking admission of Shares to the Official List and its Subsidiaries?

When a firm’s Financial Services Permission (FSP) is withdrawn and the approved status of its Approved Persons is withdrawn on the same date, does the firm still have to submit a statement to the Regulator if an Approved Person has been dismissed or requested to resign, and who must provide that statement?

If a Fund Manager or the Trustee asks for withdrawal, what must they show the Regulator about ongoing Fund management, and separately, if an Approved Person is dismissed or asked to resign, what must be sent to the Regulator and by whom?

If The Regulator tells an Institution to suspend or remove a Financial Instrument from Trading to protect investors or keep markets orderly, can this happen without warning, and if so what chance does the affected person still get to respond after the decision?

Where a Recognised Clearing House has made provision as permitted under Rule 4.5.8, what procedures must it maintain for Designated Non-Members, and how may the Default Rules then treat those Designated Non-Members compared with Members?

For an Authorised Person using the FCCA that has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, how must E be adjusted for purposes of calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount, and what calculation basis and inputs must be used to determine the substituted value?

When applying Rule 3.5.7(c) to decide whether an order is “large in scale compared with normal market size” for a Financial Instrument admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange market, how must the instrument be classified and what minimum order-size threshold applies for an instrument in the ADT band 25,000,000 < ADT <= 50,000,000?

If a Financial Instrument is admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange market, how do you decide whether an order counts as “large in scale compared with normal market size,” and what is the minimum order size if the instrument’s ADT is 500,000 or less?

For an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm, how do the obligations to maintain Capital Resources at all times and to avoid any significant risk of being unable to meet liabilities as they fall due interact, and what liquidity methods are expressly contemplated to support that outcome?

If an Authorised Person is a Domestic Firm, what must it keep in place all the time, and what are some practical ways it can manage liquidity so there is no significant risk it can’t pay its liabilities when they are due?

When a Supplementary Prospectus is filed, under what circumstances may the Regulator require a supplementary fee, and how does that fee trigger align with the broader categories of regulatory work (e.g., filing vs on-going supervision) for which supplementary fees may be imposed?

If someone files a Supplementary Prospectus, do they always have to pay an extra fee? If not, what has to happen, and how does that match the general situations where the Regulator can charge a supplementary fee (like for a filing or on-going supervision)?

If you are a Relevant Person and you are checking whether a customer’s country should push them into a high-risk rating, what kinds of documents count as “credible sources,” who can publish them, and what country issues are you looking for in those sources?

For an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm and has been imposed an Individual Capital Requirement (ICR) arising from Pillar 2 adjustments, what capital-resources maintenance duties apply on an ongoing basis, and how do the ICR-specified resources relate to the baseline capital-resources requirement under these Rules?

If an Authorised Person is a Domestic Firm and the Regulator sets an Individual Capital Requirement (ICR) for it, what does it need to keep “at all times,” and what extra buffer does it need to think about for its business risks?

For an Authorised Person that is a Branch, how should it demonstrate that it maintains adequate liquidity to avoid a significant risk of being unable to meet liabilities as they fall due, and what specific reporting and notification actions to the Regulator are triggered by its Home State Regulator prudential framework?

If an Authorised Person is a Branch, what are some practical ways it can make sure it can pay its liabilities when they are due, and what does it have to send or report to the Regulator about its Home State Regulator prudential reports or breaches?

Where the Regulator requests the documents referenced in Rule 2.4.7, what specific categories of records must an Applicant have retained, and for how long after admission to the Official List must those copies be kept so they can be provided on request?

If the Regulator asks an Applicant to hand over the documents mentioned in Rule 2.4.7, what kinds of documents should the Applicant have kept, and how long after admission to the Official List do they need to keep them?

For an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission that carries on the Regulated Activity of Providing Credit, what annual supervision fee amounts are payable to the Regulator, and in what circumstances would an additional annual supervision fee apply based on the combination of activities carried on?

If an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission provides credit, how much does it pay each year, and when would it also have to pay an extra yearly fee because it does more than one kind of regulated activity?

For the first type of Behaviour, what does it mean for an Insider to deal or attempt to deal “on the basis of” Inside Information, and how should a firm assess whether the Insider’s decision to deal in a Financial Instrument, Related Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity meets that threshold?

If an Insider trades (or tries to trade) an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity, when is that treated as being “on the basis of” Inside Information, and what link has to exist between the information and the decision to trade?

In the case of an executed Payment Transaction that was not authorised in accordance with Rule 19.10.1, what must the Payment Service Provider do, and what notification condition must be met for the Payment Service User to be entitled to redress under this Chapter (including the outer time limit measured from the debit date)?

If a Payment Service User finds out there was an executed Payment Transaction they did not authorise, what does the Payment Service Provider have to do, and by when does the user have to tell the Payment Service Provider (counting from the debit date) to be able to get redress under this Chapter?

When a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a Clearing Service using a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, what must it do to both ensure the required arrangements for clearing/settlement outcomes and to evidence those arrangements to the Regulator?

If a Recognised Investment Exchange uses a Clearing Service and the party it engages is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, what arrangements must it have in place, and what written step must it take with the Regulator?

For an Authorised Person operating as a Virtual Asset Custodian and holding Accepted Virtual Assets under custody for Clients, what statement frequency must be applied for Retail Clients, and how does that compare to the general statement cadence for Retail Clients holding Safe Custody Assets?

If an Authorised Person is a Virtual Asset Custodian and holds Accepted Virtual Assets for Clients, how often do they need to send statements to Retail Clients, and what does the general rule say about statement timing for Professional Clients?

When assessing whether a communication is an “Offer of Securities to the Public” under section 59 of FSMR, how should the firm apply the general definition of an “Offer of Securities,” including the specific exclusions for certain communications connected to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange or ongoing reporting?

If a message gives people enough details to decide whether to buy or subscribe to Securities, when does it count as an “Offer of Securities to the Public,” and when is it not counted because it is linked to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange or to ongoing reporting?

If a firm wants to (1) list Digital Securities on the Official List of Securities and (2) apply for Financial Services Permission to provide money services, what are the two fees it should expect, and how does the money services fee change depending on whether it will do Currency exchange or Money Remittance versus Payment Services?

For an Authorised Person that (i) operates as a Cell Company under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4 and wishes to add Cells after receiving its Financial Services Permission, and (ii) holds a Financial Services Permission to carry on Effecting Contracts of Insurance and/or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal, what fees must it pay to the Regulator, and how are those fees calculated (per Cell vs per Regulated Activity)?

If an Authorised Person is a Cell Company and wants to add new Cells after it already has its Financial Services Permission, and it also has permission to do Effecting Contracts of Insurance and/or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal, what payments does it owe to the Regulator and what triggers each payment?

When an Authorised Person is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets and therefore must comply with COBS, Chapter 8, how must the Chapter 8 terminology be interpreted for the purposes of Rule 17.7.2, including where Chapter 8 incorporates MIR via COBS Rule 8.2.1?

If an Authorised Person runs a Multilateral Trading Facility for Virtual Assets and has to follow COBS, Chapter 8, what words in Chapter 8 should they treat as meaning “Virtual Asset(s)” for Rule 17.7.2, including any MIR text pulled in through COBS Rule 8.2.1?

If someone is about to carry out an unsolicited Client order and they have Inside Information, what do they need to avoid doing, and how does the idea of disclosing Inside Information outside the proper course of employment/profession/duties affect that?

For an Authorised Person that (i) conducts Investment Business and (ii) conducts a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets while holding or controlling Client Money, what reconciliation frequency and completion timing must its systems and controls achieve for Client Accounts, including how the weekly requirement interacts with the minimum monthly baseline?

For purposes of Rule 7.2.1 continuous disclosure, when will the Listing Authority treat information as already “within the market” so that no separate disclosure is required, and how does that position sit alongside the periodic/financial disclosure regime in chapter 10 and the general disclosure obligations (including Prospectus Offer documents and bidders/targets statements) referenced in the Rules?

If a Listed Entity has already Disclosed the documents mentioned in paragraphs 117a) or 117b), do they still need to make a separate announcement under Rule 7.2.1, and how should they think about that answer given Rule 7.2.1’s link to chapter 10 periodic/financial disclosures and other general disclosure items like Prospectus Offer documents and bidders/targets statements?

When calculating CET1 Capital, how should an institution reconcile the TARGET’s list of eligible CET1 capital elements (including the Rule 3.10.3 condition for capital instruments and the IFRS-based reserve categories) with the SOURCE’s statement that the sum is subject to later adjustments, deductions, and exemptions in the same Part?

If you’re adding up CET1 Capital, what items do you start with (including the IFRS-based categories and the Rule 3.10.3 condition for capital instruments), and what does the SOURCE say you must still do to that total later in the same Part?

Where a Prospectus includes a statement made by a public official or contained in an official public document, how does accurate and fair reproduction of that statement affect the compensation exposure of a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, if an investor alleges loss from an untrue or misleading statement or a material omission?

If someone buys Securities covered by a Prospectus and then says they lost money because the Prospectus had a wrong statement or left out something important, when can a person who is listed in the Regulator’s Rules as liable for the Prospectus avoid liability if the disputed text came from a public official or an official public document?

For an Authorised Person evaluating Exposure to interest rate risk from Non Trading Book activities, how should the firm determine the minimum frequency of those evaluations, and what additional measurement step applies where it has balance sheet positions in different currencies?

For an Insurer preparing its balance sheet as at the Solvency Reference Date, how should it classify (i) the premium liability for policies in force and (ii) the value of reinsurance and other recoveries expected to be received for claims referred to in Rules 5.4.7 and 5.4.8, and what measurement basis applies to the recoveries?

At the Solvency Reference Date, what goes on the liability side for policies still in force, and what goes on the asset side for claims in Rules 5.4.7 and 5.4.8? Also, what standard must be used to value the recoveries?

When a Person referred to in Rule 3.7.2 is a member of the Governing Body of a Listed Fund and acquires (or changes) an interest that qualifies as a “notifiable interest” because it arises through direct or indirect ownership (including beneficial ownership) of Units or through involvement in a financial or commercial arrangement relating to the Listed Fund, what notice must be given, to whom, and within what timeframe?

If an RIE wants to run an MTF or OTF using Accepted Spot Commodities, what has to be written into its Recognition Order, what rules apply to the spot-commodity part versus the rest of its business, and what extra market does it still need to operate?

When an Authorised Person calculates its Leverage Ratio, how must it determine the Exposure Measure component, including the required aggregation of exposure categories, and how does that Exposure Measure fit into the overall Leverage Ratio methodology?

If an Authorised Person is working out its Leverage Ratio, what goes on top and what goes on the bottom, and what two types of items must be added together to get the Exposure Measure used in that calculation?

For purposes of applying the 20% placement capacity formula that limits how many Equity Securities a Listed Entity may issue without holder approval, how must the Listed Entity treat the sale or reissue of forfeited Equity Securities when calculating the “Relevant Issues” component for the prior 12-month period?

When a Listed Entity is working out how many Equity Securities it can issue without getting approval from holders of Ordinary Securities, does selling or reissuing forfeited Equity Securities count in the 12‑month “Relevant Issues” number used in the formula?

When an Authorised Person designs the strategy’s system for controlling Liquidity Risk so it can implement the requirements in Rule 9.2.6, what specific capabilities and governance features must that system include, particularly regarding review of compliance with limits and operating procedures and the presence of approval processes and mechanisms?

If the strategy has to include a system for controlling Liquidity Risk so the Authorised Person can implement Rule 9.2.6, what does that system need to let the Governing Body and senior management do, and what kinds of controls must it contain?

For an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5, when do the thresholds for Foreign Currency business and overall net open position remove the obligation to calculate a Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement, and if the thresholds are not met, what calculation approaches are permitted for Trading Book and Non Trading Book foreign exchange positions?

If an Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5, when can it skip calculating the Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement based on its Foreign Currency business and net open position, and if it cannot skip it, how does it calculate the requirement for Trading Book and Non Trading Book FX positions?

When the Regulator is seeking to transfer a Fund's property or liability to another Fund, what is the specific regulatory mechanism described for changing the applicable text, and how does that mechanism relate to the Regulator’s broader ability to modify provisions in the relevant Chapter to further its objectives?

What ongoing review arrangements must a Recognised Investment Exchange maintain to ensure a Price Reporting Agency continues to satisfy the specific procedural, transparency, governance, independence, conflict-management, and complaints-handling characteristics required for the purposes of Rules 3.11.1 and 3.11.3?

How should a Recognised Investment Exchange regularly check that a Price Reporting Agency still meets the required standards, including having public fair pricing procedures and a way to handle complaints about its methodology?

For an unmargined derivatives netting set, how should a firm determine the replacement cost (RC) using the RC formula, and how does that interact with the requirement to include an on-balance sheet value and a potential future exposure add-on when calculating the exposure value for derivatives (including written credit protection)?

If you have unmargined derivative transactions, what numbers do you plug into RC = max{V − C, 0}, and what extra pieces must be included when you calculate the exposure value for derivatives as on-balance sheet items?

When preparing the weekly position report referred to under Rule 3.3.12, how must the Recognised Investment Exchange both (i) categorise persons and (ii) distinguish between risk-reducing positions and other positions, and what classification basis and example categories should it use when applying the person-categorisation requirement?

For the weekly position report, what two kinds of sorting does the Recognised Investment Exchange need to do: one about who the people are (with examples like financial intermediary or commercial undertaking) and one about whether a position is risk-reducing or not?

Where an Authorised Person holds money received from a Professional Client under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement, how should that money be treated for Client Money classification purposes, and do the Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules apply to it?
If an Authorised Person gets money from a Professional Client under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement, is it treated as Client Money, and do the Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules apply?

For an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm, how should the Governing Body’s assessment of capital adequacy affect the firm’s obligation to maintain Capital Resources “at all times,” including any expectation to hold additional capital and liquid assets beyond the specified minimum types and amounts?

If an Authorised Person is a Domestic Firm, what does it have to keep “at all times,” and how does the Governing Body decide whether the firm should hold extra resources beyond the minimum to match its business and risks?

For an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services that undertakes the activity of a Money Remitter, how must it determine the Capital Requirement for that activity, and how is the Money Remitter Variable Capital Requirement component calculated using monthly payment volume tiers?

If an Authorised Person provides Money Services and acts as a Money Remitter, what numbers does it have to compare to set its Capital Requirement for that activity, and how do you work out the Money Remitter Variable Capital Requirement from monthly payment volume?

If an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business has to reconcile Client Accounts at least every calendar month, what does it need to keep in its Resolution Pack to show this, and what kind of control expectation goes with the monthly reconciliation rule?

When preparing a Product Summary Note for an Exempt Offer under Rule 4.3.1(13), what disclaimer-related content is the Issuer required to include, and what disclaimer-related content must the Issuer avoid including in or about the Product Summary Note?

When a Listed Entity/Reporting Entity writes its annual financial report, what does it need to say about adopting the Corporate Governance Principles, and how does that connect to the need to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of compliance?
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, how must it both (i) obtain and reflect the Competent Person(s)’ prior written consent regarding the form and context of the presentation, and (ii) include the required Competent Person statements (named person, employment/Related Party status and employer, and professional organisation membership) within that same disclosure?

Where an Authorised Person is Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets, how should the term “Investments” (and the related concept of “Client Investments”) be interpreted for the purposes of Rule 17.8.1, and what additional COBS chapter compliance obligations apply in that custody scenario (including any guidance relevant to holding or controlling Client Money)?

If an Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, how often does it have to do the evaluation of Exposure to interest rate risk from its Non Trading Book activities, and what extra measurement does it need to do because of the different currencies?

If an Authorised Person takes eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, when can it count the collateral effect for the pre-settlement exposure, and when does it have to calculate E* (and use it instead of E) because the SFT is under a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and the Authorised Person is using the FCCA?
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.

question: If someone wants to have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and those Securities are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1, what do these two passages say they need to check—both the SOURCE condition about Rule 4.4.2 and the TARGET rule about an Approved Prospectus?

If the Regulator makes a decision (or makes Rules) that could harm someone’s rights, liabilities, or interests, can that person ask the Appeals Panel for a full merits review—and does it matter if the decision is an operational decision or one of the non‑Part 21 decisions like exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers?

How should an Authorised Person be categorised where its Financial Services Permission includes Managing Assets and it also undertakes Dealing in Investments as Agent, but only in a way that is wholly incidental to Managing Assets; and how does that interact with the Category 2 test for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal) and the requirement that dealing activities are not limited in scope?
target_text:
An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal);
(b)	its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and
(c)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5.
Category 3A
Guidance
A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.

question: Does a Reporting Entity have to appoint an auditor, and if so, what rules must it follow when making that appointment?
source_text: A Reporting Entity is required under section 82 of the FSMR to appoint an auditor.
target_text:
Financial reports. Appointment of auditors
A Reporting Entity shall have an auditor Appointed in accordance with ‎Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part.

question: If a Recognised Body cannot follow a direction (like giving access for inspection or suspending an activity), what can the Regulator do, and when does it usually consider revoking the Recognition Order?

question: For a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity, what is the latest time by which it must disclose the quarterly report, and what minimum subject-matter must that quarterly report cover for the entity and all controlled entities on a consolidated basis (if applicable)?
source_text: Quarterly Reports – Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entities. A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose the report required by Rule 12.13.1 no later than one month after the end of the quarter.

question: If the Listing Authority’s enquiry leads it to think the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not exempt, and it believes the information should have been disclosed earlier, what does an ‘aware letter’ usually ask the Reporting Entity to confirm, and when is the Listing Authority allowed to send that letter (instead of only asking for a disclosure)?
source_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Complaints or allegations of non-compliance by Reporting Entities
If, as a result of the enquiry, the Listing Authority forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within exemption from Disclosure provided by Rule 7.2.2, the Listing Authority will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1.  If the information should have been Disclosed earlier, the Listing Authority may issue an ‘aware letter’ (see paragraphs 187 to 189 above), or take other relevant action.
target_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Aware Letters
Similar to a MAQ Letter, ‘aware letters’ tend to follow a standard template.  Generally, they will identify the information in question and the relevant date it was Disclosed, and ask the following questions:

(i)	Does the Reporting Entity believe the information identified in the letter to be Inside Information (being information that a reasonable person would expect to have a significant effect on the price of the Listed Entity’s Securities)?

(ii)	If the answer to question i) is “yes”, please confirm the following:

i.	When did the Reporting Entity first become aware of the Inside Information identified in the letter? Please include details of the relevant time and circumstances of the Reporting Entity becoming aware of the [key contents of the Inside Information]?

ii.	If the Reporting Entity was aware of the [key contents of the Inside Information] prior to the date of this letter, please advise why the Reporting Entity did not Disclose the Inside Information or request a Trading Halt or Suspension at an earlier time?  Please comment specifically on the application of Rule 7.2.1.

(iii)	If the answer to question i) is “no”, please confirm the basis on which the Reporting Entity does not consider the information to be Inside Information?

(iv)	Please confirm that the Reporting Entity is in compliance with the Markets Rules and, in particular, Rule 7.2.1.

question: When the Regulator considers a Fund or Sub Fund name to be undesirable, misleading, or conflicting with another Fund or Sub-Fund name, may it issue a direction requiring the Fund Manager to change that name, and how does this relate to the Regulator’s broader ability to direct changes where a class of Units name is also problematic?
source_text: Pursuant to Section 117 of FSMR, the Regulator has the power to make a direction if a name of a Fund, Sub-Fund or class of Units in a Fund is undesirable, misleading or conflicts with a name used by another Fund, Sub-Fund or class of Units of a Fund.

Power to make a Direction
If, in the opinion of the Regulator, the name of a Fund or of a Sub Fund conflicts with the name of another Fund or Sub-Fund or is undesirable or misleading, it may direct the Fund Manager to change the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity prepares a disclosure under a Mining Reporting Standard, how must it address non-mandatory requirements—particularly where it does not fully comply with them—and what explanation must be included in the disclosure?
source_text: Rule 11.2.1(1) requires a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all binding requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard. The Regulator also expects a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all non-mandatory requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard, including, for example, Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code, or explain its non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2.
target_text: Requirements for all disclosures. Where a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in a Mining Reporting Standard, the Mining Reporting Entity must provide in its disclosure a statement as to how and why its disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard.

question: If a Listed Entity does not fully follow APP 4, what does it have to say in its annual financial report about the reasons and what it did instead, and what does the Regulator expect to be disclosed in the Prospectus and then later on?
source_text: Generally, if a Reporting Entity does not adopt the best practice standards set out in APP 4, or adopts them only partially, the Regulator would expect the reasons for doing so and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the outcomes intended by the Corporate Governance Principles to be disclosed in the Prospectus and thereafter pursuant to the Disclosure required under Rule 9.2.10. Any inaccurate or false representations would lead to the imposition of civil liability in accordance with section 70 of the FSMR.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

If the Regulator sends a collateral notice, how can the Regulator decide the value limit for the assets a Captive Insurer must make available, and how is that limit worked out in the case of a Long-Term Insurance Fund?
source_text:
The amount referred to in Rule ‎10.3.2(1)(b) is calculated as follows:
(a)	in the case of a Captive Cell of a Captive Insurer which is a Cell Company, the sum of the following two amounts:
(i)	the Insurance Liabilities attributable to that Captive Cell; and
(ii)	the Minimum Cellular Capital Requirement applicable to that Captive Cell.
(b)	in the case of a Long-Term Insurance Fund, subject to Rules ‎10.3.2(4)(c) and ‎10.3.2(4)(d), the sum of the following two amounts:
(i)	the Insurance Liabilities attributable to that Long-Term Insurance Fund; and
(ii)	the Minimum Fund Capital Requirement applicable to that Long-Term Insurance Fund;
(c)	in the case of a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company, the sum of the following two amounts:
(i)	the Captive Insurer's Insurance Liabilities; and
(ii)	the Captive Insurer's minimum capital requirement as provided for in Rule 2.2.
(d)	in the case of a Captive Insurer to which Rules ‎10.3.2(4)(a) and ‎10.3.2(4)(c) both apply, the amount set out in ‎10.3.2(4)(a); and
(e)	in the case of a Captive Insurer to which Rules ‎10.3.2(4)(c) and ‎10.3.2(4)(d) both apply, the amount set out in Rule ‎10.3.2(4)(d).
target_text:
The Regulator may, by written notice (referred to in this Chapter as a 'collateral notice'), require a Captive Insurer to make available assets:
(a)	of a type and in a manner described in Rule ‎10.3.2(5); and
(b)	having a value, determined in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 6, of the lower of:
(i)	the amount, if any, specified in the notice; and
(ii)	the amount determined in accordance with Rule ‎10.3.2(4).

question: In defining when a filed Prospectus becomes an Approved Prospectus, how do the Regulations’ general test for approval under the Rules interact with the requirement that the Regulator issue an approval notice to the Applicant, including where the Prospectus consists of multiple documents?

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity withholds detail of material economic assumptions on the basis of commercial sensitivity, what must it include in its disclosure to substantiate that position, and how should it assess whether the claim is credible where no commercially sensitive contracts underpin commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure assumptions?
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text: ORE RESERVES . Mining Reporting Entities need to be careful not to claim that information is commercially sensitive when this is not the case.  If a Mining Reporting Entity, for example, has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin its commodity price, capital expenditure or operational expenditure assumptions, it would be difficult to form a view that information about those assumptions would be commercially sensitive.

question: Where a trader rapidly accumulates control of more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract on a Commodity Derivative Exchange and then exits the position in the final settlement window at escalating prices, how should this conduct be assessed against the definition of Behaviour that involves effecting transactions or orders to trade other than for legitimate reasons and not in conformity with Accepted Market Practices, particularly in relation to creating a misleading impression of supply/demand or securing an abnormal or artificial price level?
source_text:
Abusive squeezes. The following are specific examples of an abusive squeeze that, in the Regulator's view, may contravene section 92 (4)(b):
(a)	during the course of a trading day on a Commodity Derivative Exchange, a trader rapidly builds up a position of more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract.  The trader fails to Offer to lend the crude oil back to other market participants at a reasonable commercial rate.  The trader then unwinds his position in the Exchange's final settlement window  at rapidly increasing prices, thereby cornering/squeezing the crude oil market.  His conduct causes an abnormal movement in the price of crude oil contracts for forward month delivery; and
(b)	a trader with a long position in bond futures, buys or borrows a large amount of the bonds and either refuses to re-lend these bonds or will only lend them to parties he believes will not re-lend to the market.  His purpose is to position the price at which persons with short positions have to deliver to satisfy their obligations at a materially higher level, making him a profit on his position.
target_text:
The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which—
(a)	give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or
(b)	secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.
