question: When a Mining Reporting Entity prepares forecast financial information, what must it include regarding the material economic assumptions used, and how must it handle any claim that those assumptions are commercially sensitive so that the Disclosure remains fair and balanced and does not improperly rely on trade-secret characterisation?
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

When a Recognised Clearing House is providing Central Counterparty Services, what must it do with the results of its stress tests in assessing its total financial resources, and how does the applicability of that obligation depend on the service scope described?

In the context of an investigation, when may the Investigator compel attendance at an interview and questioning, and does that authority extend beyond the Person Under Investigation to other individuals regardless of any connection to that person, provided the requirement is issued by written notice?

Can the Investigator make someone come to an interview and answer questions during an investigation, and can that include people other than the Person Under Investigation if the Investigator sends a written notice?

For a Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities, when must it apply the restriction in APP 7, and in what circumstances are specified APP 7 restriction categories treated as not applying unless the Regulator decides otherwise?

When an Authorised Person identifies that it does not hold, or is likely not to hold, the capital needed to meet its ongoing Tier 1 Capital and minimum Leverage Ratio requirement, what notification must it provide to the Regulator, in what form, and how quickly must it be made?

How should an Authorised Person reconcile its duty to maintain a minimum Leverage Ratio through sufficient Tier 1 Capital with its duty to alert the Regulator where its capital position may no longer support that requirement, including the timing and medium of any alert?

What are the two connected duties for an Authorised Person about (1) keeping its leverage ratio through Tier 1 Capital and (2) telling the Regulator when it cannot, or may soon not be able to, meet that capital need?

When conducting an investigation, in what circumstances may the Investigator compel the Person Under Investigation or another person (including someone not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to provide information, and what kinds of material can fall within the scope of “information” for that purpose?

How may the Investigator use a written notice to require a person to answer questions or otherwise provide information, and how should a regulated party assess whether the requested content qualifies as “information” rather than only “Documents”?
Can the Investigator make someone give information during an investigation, and does this apply only to the Person Under Investigation or also to other people? What does “information” cover?

If the Investigator asks for “information” in a written notice, does that mean only documents, or can it include answers and computer data too? How does this fit with the Investigator’s ability to require interviews and questions?

When an Authorised Person has Non Trading Book assets or liabilities denominated in multiple currencies, how must it determine which currencies are treated as material for purposes of measuring interest rate risk Exposure, and what evaluation and measurement steps must follow for those currencies?

When a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction, how must it deliver the refusal notification to the Customer, and what must the Governing Contract include to evidence the agreed means of communication for transmitting such notifications (including any technical requirements)?

If a Third Party Provider intends to reserve the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed, what must it do when it refuses a Third Party Transaction, and how must the Governing Contract address both the reservation of that right and the agreed notification method?

When an Authorised Person has a CR Exposure to a qualifying multilateral development bank, what risk weight must be applied, and in what way may guarantees from MDBs be recognised as eligible credit risk mitigation in relation to that exposure?

If an Authorised Person has a credit exposure to one of the listed MDBs, what risk weight must be used, and can the Authorised Person also treat an MDB-provided guarantee as an eligible guarantee for credit risk mitigation?

If the Regulator is asked to approve a replacement of a Trustee, how must the Fund Manager demonstrate that the incoming Trustee will be independent of the Fund Manager, and what alternative Unitholder or certification pathway can support the approval request?

If a Fund Manager wants to replace the Trustee, what must be true about the new Trustee’s independence from the Fund Manager, and what documents must the Regulator receive before it can approve the replacement?

When an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business is permitted to pay, or permit to be paid, Client Money to a Third-Party Agent, what specific record relating to that permission must be included in the Authorised Person’s Resolution Pack, and what condition must be satisfied before the payment is allowed?
If an Authorised Person wants to send Client Money to a Third-Party Agent, what must it do first, and what paperwork about that step has to be kept in the Resolution Pack?

If an Exposure is partly covered by a guarantee from an Authorised Person’s Parent Financial Institution, is the Authorised Person prohibited from ignoring the whole Exposure when checking whether it has a Large Exposure above the Tier 1 limit, or can it ignore only the guaranteed part after factoring in eligible CRM?

How must an Authorised Person operationalise daily monitoring and control of its Exposures so that it remains within the applicable Large Exposures limits, including the requirement to keep the aggregate of its Large Exposures within the Tier 1-based cap?

What must an Authorised Person do each day to track and manage its Exposures so it stays within the Large Exposures limits, and how does this link to the rule that caps the total of its Large Exposures as a percentage of Tier 1?

When the Rules distinguish between an Authorised Person operating as a Branch versus operating as a Domestic Firm, what capital-resources obligations must be met by the Authorised Person that falls within the Domestic Firm category, and how does that scope boundary affect the applicability of those obligations?

If an Authorised Person is operating as a Domestic Firm (not as a Branch), what must it do to maintain capital resources and liquidity, and why does the operating category matter for which Rules apply?

When calculating CET1 Capital, what exclusions must an Authorised Person apply, and how must it ensure those required exclusions are implemented without making prohibited fair-value adjustments to remove unrealised gains or losses from its Capital Resources (other than the limited carve-out referenced in the prohibition)?

For CET1 Capital, what items must an Authorised Person leave out, and what does it mean that it generally must not adjust its Capital Resources just to strip out unrealised fair-value gains or losses (apart from the limited carve-out mentioned)?

If the Regulator treats a Listed Entity as not subject to certain APP 7 restriction categories because it qualifies for admission and meets the profitability/revenue or tangible-asset test, can the Controller still avoid signing the Restriction Agreement, and when is that allowed?

What must a Listed Entity ensure is built into its constitution to support enforceability of Restriction Agreements, and how does this obligation align with the requirement that an Applicant operate in conformity with its constitution as part of being validly established under the laws of its place of incorporation or establishment?

What do Listed Entities need to put in their constitution so Restriction Agreements can be enforced, and what does an Applicant have to do to show it is properly set up and following its constitution?

For an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 that is also an Authorised Person Managing a PSIA which is an Unrestricted PSIA, what exposures are prohibited when considering (i) Financial Group Large Exposure (including the Financial Group's PSIAus) relative to the Group’s Tier 1 and (ii) Exposure to a Counterparty or related counterparty group relative to Capital Resources, including where the exposure is financed by Capital Resources and/or Unrestricted PSIAs?

If an Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2 or 5 and also manages an Unrestricted PSIA, what must it not do regarding (1) Financial Group Large Exposure (including the Financial Group’s PSIAus) and (2) exposure to a counterparty or related counterparty group, and what percentage limits apply in each case?

If extra work is expected for FSRA/the Regulator—like when an application or ongoing supervision needs substantial additional effort—can the Regulator charge extra fees, and what should the Applicant/Authorised Person do to avoid surprises?

If the FSRA is checking whether a Digital Settlement Facility has good arrangements to make sure trades settle on time, what parts of the DSF’s processes can the FSRA look at, and does a Recognised Clearing House automatically fail its Recognition Requirement if one specific transaction cannot be settled?

If an MTF (using Virtual Assets) is treated as being covered by the notification rules that normally apply to Recognised Investment Exchanges, what does a Recognised Body have to tell the Regulator when it plans to appoint a new Key Individual, and how far in advance must it do this?

When the extra notification requirements for MTFs (using Virtual Assets) apply, what does a Recognised Body need to report to the Regulator if a Key Individual resigns or stops being a Key Individual, and when must it report it?

When an Authorised Person determines its Credit RWA as an aggregate measure, how must it treat the RWA component for Credit Risk Exposures in terms of which balance sheet and off balance sheet items are included, and which categories of exposures must be excluded so that the CR Exposure component aligns with the overall sum-of-components approach?

If an Authorised Person is working out its Credit RWA as the total of different RWA parts, what items must it count in the CR Exposures part, and what exposures must it leave out so they are handled in the other parts of the total?
Who does this Chapter apply to, and for those covered, what is different about Category 3A firms versus Category 2 firms when it comes to using the Simplified Approach?

When a Mining Reporting Entity is permitted to disclose a Production Target in relation to its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or a material Mining Project, in what circumstances may a later Production Target disclosure omit the otherwise required supporting information, and what specific confirmations and cross-references must that later disclosure include?

If a Mining Reporting Entity discloses a Production Target for its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or for a material Mining Project, when can it make a later Production Target disclosure without repeating all the detailed information, and what does it still have to say in that later disclosure?

Where a Low-Value Payment Instrument is used in relation to both Payment Accounts and Stored Value, and it is governed by a Framework Contract, what is the resulting scope of the Payment Service Provider’s disclosure obligations to the Payer and what information may be provided in place of the general and transaction-level information otherwise expected?

If a Low-Value Payment Instrument is used for both Payment Accounts and Stored Value, and it sits under a Framework Contract, what does the Payment Service Provider have to tell the Payer, and what disclosures can be reduced or replaced?

When an Authorised Person becomes aware of a notifiable event that could affect whether a person has become an unacceptable Controller, what must the Authorised Person do, and how may the Regulator use that notification in its assessment?

How should an Authorised Person align its written notification timing duties with the Regulator’s ability to consider, based on notifications and supervisory work, whether a person has become an unacceptable Controller?

If an Authorised Person learns about a reportable event that might change whether someone is an unacceptable Controller, what does the Authorised Person have to do, and what can the Regulator do with that information?

Where a person has formed an intention to deal in a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset, or an Accepted Spot Commodity, how should compliance assess whether executing that intention is permitted when the person may also possess information that meets the definition of Inside Information for those instruments?

In the context of dealing in Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities, what is the compliance distinction between a person merely implementing their pre-formed trading intention and a scenario where the person’s decision-making may be influenced by information that qualifies as Inside Information?

If a person decides to trade and then follows through on that plan, when is that allowed, and how do you check whether the person also has Inside Information about the Financial Instrument, Accepted Virtual Asset, or Accepted Spot Commodity?

A person has a trading plan for an Accepted Virtual Asset or Accepted Spot Commodity. Does carrying out that plan automatically break the rules, and what counts as Inside Information that would raise a concern?

Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, how must the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider treat the notification deadline that conditions entitlement to redress for an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transaction—must the Payment Service User still notify without undue delay and within twelve months, or may the parties agree in writing to a different time period, and what is the effect on redress eligibility?

If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, does it still have to tell its Payment Service Provider about an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transaction within twelve months to get redress, or can both sides agree in writing to use a different time limit?
